markdownRemark.html:
Taylor expansion

The Taylor series of a real or complex-valued function f(x) that is infinitely differentiable at a real or complex number a is the power series [1]

n=0∑∞​n!f(n)(a)​(x−a)n=f(a)+1!f′(a)​(x−a)+2!f′′(a)​(x−a)2+3!f′′′(a)​(x−a)3+…

The taylor polynomial for any polynomial is the polynomial itself. When a=0 the series is also called the a Maclaurin series. The series is very useful to approximate a function at a as a polynomial. Here we approximate sin at a=0

sin(x)≈x−3!x3​+5!x5​−7!x7​+O(x9)

where O(x9) is the error term.

Differentiability class

The function f is said to be of differentiability class Ck if the derivatives f(1),f(2),…,f(k) exist and are continous.

Gradient

Suppose that f:Rn→R is a function and that f∈C1 we can define the gradient ∇f as

∇f=⎣⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎡​∂x1​∂f​∂x2​∂f​⋮∂xn​∂f​​⎦⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎤​

Hessian

Suppose that f:Rn→R is a function taking as input a vector x∈Rn and output a scalar f(x)∈R. If f∈C2 then the Hessian matrix H of f is a square n×n matrix defined as follows

H=⎣⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎡​∂x12​∂2f​∂x2​∂x1​∂2f​⋮∂xn​∂x1​∂2f​​∂x1​∂x2​∂2f​∂x22​∂2f​⋮∂xn​∂x2​∂2f​​⋯⋯⋱⋯​∂x1​∂xn​∂2f​∂x2​∂xn​∂2f​⋮∂xn2​∂2f​​⎦⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎤​
